The  Local  Government  Code  (LGC),  1991,  transferred  the  main 
responsibility 
in  health, 
education,  infrastructure,  etc.,  to  local  government  units  (LGUs), 
which are provinces, cities, municipalities, and barangays (villages 
or neighborhoods). Decentralization has brought choices closer to 
the  people while  opening  up space  for  innovative  responses  and 
solutions  to  service  delivery  issues.  The  LGC’s  “finance  follows 
function”  premise  set  in  place  an  intergovernmental  transfer 
mechanism  for  sharing  the  revenues  of  the  Government  of  the 
Philippines (the Government) while allowing local governments to 
raise their own revenues. However, LGUs’ capability to discharge 
their  functions  is  constrained,  as  the  Philippines  still  faces 
challenges  in  ensuring  that  stable  mechanisms  function  to 
channel  adequate  resources  to  local  governments.  Financial 
accountability,  transparency,  and  capacity  are  also  significant 
constraints on local governments.

LGUs’ access to development credit, service delivery by financing

intended  impact  will  be  achieved  by  (i) strengthening  the  policy,

1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
for  subprogram  2  to  the  Republic  of  the  Philippines  for  the  Local  Government  Financing  and 
Budget  Reform  (LGFBR)  Program.  The  LGFBR  is  a  program  cluster  comprising  two

II. 

THE MACROECONOMIC CONTEXT 

2. 
Global  financial  crisis  and  Government  response.  The  economic  expansion  of 
Philippines  has  been  notable  in  the  past  5  years  with  sound  macroeconomic  policies,  fiscal 
consolidation  targets  on  track,  and  a  favorable  external  economic  environment.  Growth  has 
been steady and rising, culminating in a 3-decade high of 7.2% in 2007. However, the economic 
expansion  in  the  past  5  years  has  not  translated  into  substantial  poverty  reduction.  Data  from 
the Government shows that income poverty increased from 30% in 2003 to 32.9% in 2006. In 
addition, a forthcoming ADB report shows that inequality in the Philippines is among the worst in 
Southeast  Asia,  with  a  Gini  coefficient  of  43.97,  higher  than  38.05  for  Cambodia,  34.3  for 
Indonesia,  34.68  for  the  Lao  People’s  Democratic  Republic,  and  40.33  for  Malaysia. 1  The 
Medium-Term  Philippine  Development  Plan  (MTPDP)  2004–2010  postulates  that  poverty  is 
mainly a rural phenomenon, though urban poverty is on the rise and poverty levels vary greatly 
by  region.2 There  are  regions  where  poverty  incidence  has  been  persistently  high  (such  as 
Caraga  and  regions  V,  VIII,  IX,  and  IV-B).  The  MTPDP  emphasizes  the  role  of  local 
governments in the fight against poverty. 
 
3. 
While  sustained  high  growth  would  have  contributed  to  significant  poverty  reduction, 
external  shocks  have  recently  come  into  play.  In  2008,  gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  growth 
slowed  sharply,  reflecting  the  effects  of  high  inflation  especially  affecting  prime  commodities. 
This was reinforced by the global financial crisis and growth slowdown, which weakened global 
demand.  The  Philippines  was  hard-hit  first  by  more  restricted  access  to  capital  markets  and 
subsequently by slowing remittances and a fall in exports. Prospects for growth remain weak in 
2009,  as  further  deceleration  of  the  Philippine  economy  is  expected  with  the  weakening  of 
global demand for Philippine exports, including labor. The likely further dampening of domestic 
demand and investment will bring higher unemployment and a further setback in the antipoverty 
efforts of the Government and the achievement of the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs).3

4. 
In  early  2009,  the  Government  announced  a  P330  billion  ($6.9  billion)  fiscal  stimulus 
package  to  counter  the  effects  of  weakening  external  demand  and  boost  domestic  economic 
activity, comprising (i) a P160 billion budget appropriation in 2009 to expand welfare programs 
such  as  cash  transfers  to  poor  families  and  road  maintenance,  (ii)  P100  billion  for  large 
infrastructure projects to be funded by Government corporations and social security institutions, 
and (iii) P70 billion in tax breaks.4

6. 
Role  of  local  governments  in  development  strategy.  The  deteriorating  external 
environment and its impact on the domestic economy brings to the fore the critical role of local 
governments in stimulating domestic demand in the short run and supporting the development 
agenda  of  the  country  in  the  medium  term.  It  is  therefore  important  to  strengthen  the  link 
between  national  plans  and  local  government  plans  and  programs.  The  trickle-down  effect  of 
the fiscal stimulus package will be maximized only if local governments have effective service-
delivery mechanisms. Local governments need to be supported in the development agenda with 
performance-based incentives that make them more efficient. With increased resources coming 
from  the  national  Government,  public  financial  management  systems  and  accountability 
mechanisms need to be further strengthened. Local governments must not rely only on national 
Government transfers to finance development; other sources of credit financing, especially own-
source revenue, are critical in an environment where national tax collection is sluggish because 
of the economic slowdown.

10. 
Evolving  administrative  and  legal  framework.  Since the passage of LGC many bills 
have been filed in Congress asking for omnibus amendments to it, increasing LGUs’ IRA shares 
and  creating  new  LGUs.  In  2007,  a  bill  was  drafted  with  ADB  TA9 focusing  on  amending  the 
local tax provisions of the code. Consultation with LGU leagues and oversight agencies resulted 
in a final draft endorsed by the stakeholders.10 The objective of the bill is to improve own-source 
income from local taxes by removing low and unrealistic ceilings on local tax rates (which have 
not been adjusted for inflation since 1991), eliminating subjectivity in the interpretation of the law 
(e.g.,  the  definition  of  amusement  establishments),  and  simplifying  complicated  tax  schedules 
that  can  facilitate  corruption  (e.g.,  the  schedule of  business taxes).  Stakeholders  are  currently 
advocating bill passage to the LGU subcommittees of both houses of Congress.

1. 

Completeness, Timeliness, and Transparency in Intergovernmental Fiscal 
Transfers 

 
27. 
National transfers. Government transfers to LGUs are of three types: (i) formula-based 
block  grants  (i.e.,  IRA);  (ii)  origin-based  share  in  national Government  revenues  (i.e.,  share  in 
national  wealth  and  other  taxes);  and  (iii)  ad  hoc  categorical  grants.  Under  the  LGC,  the 
aggregate  IRA  of  LGUs  is  set  at  40%  of  the  actual  internal  revenue  tax  collections  of  the 
Government  3  years  prior  to  the  current  year.  The  aggregate  IRA  is  then  divided  among 

 

 12 

 

different  local  government  levels  as  follows:  23%  to  provinces,  23%  to  cities,  34%  to 
municipalities,  and  20%  to  barangays.  The  IRA  share  of  each  tier  of  local  government  is  then 
apportioned to individual LGUs based on population (50%), land area (25%), and equal sharing 
(25%).15  
 
28. 
IRA  is  the  most  significant  revenue  source,  especially  for  LGUs  in  the  third  to  sixth 
income  classes.16 For  example,  IRA  accounts  for  88%  of  the  regular  income  of  third  income 
class provinces, 94.5% of fourth income class provinces, and 80% of third to fifth income class 
municipalities.17 IRA surged from 3.3% of government expenditures in 1985–1991 to 17.1% of 
government  expenditures  in  2008.  The  contribution  of  the  IRA  to  total  LGU  income  net  of 
borrowings expanded from 36.7% in 1985–1991 to 64.6% in 1992–2008 for all LGUs (Table 8). 
The  lack  of  reliability  in  the  release  of  IRA  plagued  the  intergovernmental  transfer  system  for 
many years. It not only affected LGUs’ ability to budget and plan effectively but also limited their 
access to finances, since creditors rely heavily on the IRA deposits as collateral. The transfers 
evolved  into  a  highly  unpredictable  revenue  source  between  1998  and  2004  as  the 
Government,  faced  with  fiscal  constraints,  persistently  reduced  the  amount  due  to  LGUs  until 
the Supreme Court ruled that IRA should be automatically released.

Effective Performance Measurement System 

 
33. 
Issues.  The  local  governance  performance  management  system  (LGPMS)  provides 
LGUs  with  a  tool  to  assess  their  strengths  and  weaknesses  in  governance,  administration, 
social  services,  and  economic  development.  The  input  and  output  indicators  measure 
performance  in  17  service  areas  that  include  transparency,  participation,  revenue  generation, 
financial  accountability,  human  resource  management,  social  services  (health,  education,  and 
housing),  agriculture  and  fishery  development,  and  business  promotion.  DILG,  in  cooperation 
with DOF, DBM, and NEDA, continuously fine-tunes and improves the LGPMS by improving its 
architecture  and  developing  a  framework  for  use  by  executive  agencies.  BLGF  has  set  up  a 
database  called  the  local  government  financial  performance  monitoring  system  (LGFPMS), 
which  is  being  linked  to  the  LGPMS  to  allow  financial  data  to  be  integrated  with  development 
and  service  delivery  data  and  to  strengthen  the  linkage  between  measuring  outputs  and 
allocating inputs.  
 
34. 
Progress  and  opportunities.  Subprogram  1  achievements  to  enhance  effectiveness 
and transparency in the local delivery of critical public services and enhance financing options to 
improve service delivery in key sectors are the (i) provision to over 200 lower-income LGUs of 
access  to  financing  for  improved  service  delivery  in  infrastructure  and  public  services;  (ii) 
implementation of the LGPMS in all LGUs; and (iii) integration of the LGFPMS into the LGPMS. 
The  significance  of  these  achievements  is  that  equal  importance  is  being  placed  on  providing 
resources  for  local  services  and  on  measuring  performance  in  the  delivery  of  these  services. 
Perceived  as  a  two-track  reform  in  subprogram  1,  the  framework  converges  in  subprogram  2 
through  the  adoption  of  performance-based  grants  and  linkages  to  the  policy  area  on  credit 
financing. There is a need to continue providing financing in other areas of service delivery and 
develop  innovative  modalities  of  financing  that  can  be  tied  to  good  performance  in  fiscal 
governance.  The  reforms  should  aim  to  link  incentives  and  appropriate  performance 
measurement with good fiscal and expenditure management and effective local service delivery.  
 

4. 

Access of LGUs to Development Credit Financing  

 
35. 
Issues.  Credit  financing  is  used  by  LGUs  to  develop  infrastructure  and  make  capital 
investments.  Credit  sources  include  domestic  banks,  government  financial  institutions  (GFIs), 
and  loans  through  the  Government  from  foreign  sources.  Although  LGUs  are  empowered  to 
borrow,  the  LGC  puts  a  ceiling  on  debt  servicing,  which  should  not  exceed  20%  of  regular 
income.  The  Government’s  long-term  vision  is  for  the  capital  market,  rather  than  national 
agencies,  to  play  the  dominant  role  in  financing  LGUs.  However,  private  lending  is  still 
insubstantial. GFIs and  MDFO continue to be the dominant  sources of LGU financing. Private 
banks  have  indicated  that  the  mandated  use  of  GFIs  as  depository  banks  for  LGUs  is  a 

 

  

15

significant structural impediment to private banks’ entry into the market lending to LGUs. This is 
compounded by the lack of reliable information on LGU creditworthiness.  
 
36. 
Progress  and  opportunities.  Subprogram  1  records  the  following  achievements  in 
improving  LGU  access  to  public  and  private  sources  of  financing  for  policy  reforms  and 
development  projects:  (i)  the  issuance  of  the  LGU  financing  framework  as  a  national  policy 
delineating the financing market for LGUs between private and government credit providers; (ii) 
the  issuance  of  guiding  principles  for  national  government–LGU  cost-sharing  by  the  NEDA 
Investment Coordinating Committee and DOF, for evaluating and processing projects involving 
devolved  services;  (iii) P2  billion  allocated  for  program  (policy)  lending;  (iv)  the  opening  of  a 
financing window for LGU projects supporting the MDGs in fourth- to sixth-class municipalities 
with an initial funding of P500 million; and (v) the creation of a loan facility with a performance 
based grant component.  The significance of this policy area is twofold. First, it establishes and 
reconfirms  the  role  of  government  direct-financing  facilities  as  providers  of  credit  for 
development projects not attractive to private lenders due to lower returns. Second, it links up 
with the policy area of performance measurement and introduces a new governance dimension 
to  credit  financing.  MDFO  has  directed  its  resources  for  improving  governance  (e.g.,  by 
establishing  a  program  lending  facility  [PROLEND])  and  investing  in  basic  needs  projects  and 
rural development. In addition, MDFO conducted a pilot phase by adopting a sector approach to 
a  performance-based  system  to  set  the  stage  for  linking  this  policy  area  with  performance 
measurement by providing incentives for good performance. Future reforms need to strengthen 
the links between private financing and LGUs,  as well as access more development financing 
by  rationalizing  and  improving  the  use  of  official  development  assistance  (ODA)  for  LGU 
projects,  improving  direct  credit  financing  to  lower-income  LGUs,  and  further  enhancing  LGU 
access to private capital markets.

Improving  personnel  expenditure  policy.  With  the  passage  of  the  LGC,  LGUs  are 
given responsibility for a wide range of functions, including some that were previously assigned 
to  national  Government  agencies.  Concomitant  with  the  devolution  of  functions  from  national 
Government agencies, a significant number of personnel from these agencies were transferred 
to the rolls of the LGUs. Further, LGUs created new offices and hired additional staff for newly 
assigned  functions,  even  in  cases  where  no  personnel  were  devolved  from  national 
Government  agencies.  The  expansion  of  existing  functions  and  absorption  of  new  ones  by 
LGUs pursuant to the expenditure assignments mandated under the LGC have thus resulted in 
the growth of their organization and the increase in the number of LGU staff.  
 
21. 
At the same time, LGUs had to contend with legislated increases in government salaries 
and allowances, particularly under the second wave of the Salary Standardization Law. These 
developments  have  necessarily  increased  spending  on  personnel  relative  to  Maintenance  and 
Other Operating Expenditures (MOOE) before LGC promulgation. Although central Government 
transfers,  mainly  IRA,  have  increased  substantially  with  the  implementation  of  the  LGC,  local 
demand for more and higher-quality services has increased pressure on LGUs to deliver these 
services more efficiently and effectively while working within hard budget constraints.  
 
22. 
As  a  corollary  to  the  downtrend  in  LGU  income,  LGU  spending  shrank  from  4.1%  of 
GDP in 2000 to 3.2% of GDP in 2007. Thus, although the budget share of personnel was fairly 
stable during the period (Table A8.10), total LGU spending on personnel declined from 1.8% of 
GDP in 2000 to 1.4% of GDP in 2007, indicative of the erosion of real wages in the entire public 
sector, not just in LGUs, since 2000. Total LGU spending on maintenance and other operating 
expenditures  went  down  as  well,  from  1.5%  of  GDP  to  1.2%,  as  capital  outlays  dropped  from 
0.8%  of  GDP  to  0.6%.  Given  pending  proposals  to  implement  another  round  of  salary 
adjustments as part of the third wave of the salary standardization initiative, the need to secure 
effective control over the public sector wage bill becomes even more imperative, as spending on 
personnel  already  accounted  for  a  significant  portion  of  total  LGU  spending  (43%–47%)  in 
2000–2007. Otherwise, LGUs risk further diminution of the quantity and quality of local services 
because an increase in the wage bill will likely put the squeeze on maintenance, other operating 
expenditures, and capital outlays, which are just as essential as wages in local service delivery. 
It  is  likely  that  local  economic  development  will  be  severely  compromised  if  LGU  spending  on 
personnel eats up an even larger part of their budgets, as LGUs become less able to improve 
local infrastructure. Yet, if government pay is not adjusted, as is now being proposed to address 
the erosion of public sector wages and to decompress public sector wages, government will find 
it difficult to recruit and retain quality staff, encourage productivity, and avoid corruption. 
 
A  host  of  other  staffing  and  compensation  issues  have  emerged  after  devolution  and 
23. 
created  dysfunctions  in  the  local  bureaucracy.  First,  devolved  personnel  retained  their  pay 
scales  and  thus  were  getting  first-class  rates,  regardless  of  the  income  class  of  the  LGU  that 
absorbed  them.  Second,  devolved  health  personnel  receive  Magna  Carta  for  Health  Workers 
benefits. The higher rates given to devolved personnel and their benefits from the Magna Carta 
created  some  conflict  in  LGUs.  Third,  some  of  the  devolved  positions  created  redundancy  in 
LGU staffing. There is thus a need to review policies on the organization, position structure, and 
compensation of LGUs, as they significantly affect local budget allocation and prioritization.

A.    Linkages to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  
 
The Medium-Term Philippine Development Plan 2004–2010 (MTPDP) notes that Philippine poverty is basically rural poverty, 
since almost three out of four of the poor reside in the rural areas. The MTPDP further elaborates that rural poverty remains 
tied  to  the  state  of  agriculture  and  the  environment.  The  rural  poor—mainly  smallholder  or  landless  farmers,  fisherfolk,  and 
indigenous  people—continue  to  lack  access  to  productive  resources  including  land,  credit,  technology,  and  infrastructure. 
What complicates this is the uneven nature and degree of poverty across regions and provinces. The Bicol region, Eastern 
Visayas,  and  Autonomous  Region  in  Muslim  Mindanao  are  the  primary  areas  where  the  incidence  and  depth  of  poverty  is 
highest.  
 
The MTPDP outlines an action plan for poverty reduction and the attainment of the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) 
through a broad and strategic partnership among various interest groups and stakeholders, including local government units 
(LGUs). The role of local governments in the national agenda of poverty reduction is anchored in the Local Government Code, 
1991,  provision  that  declared  it  “the  policy  of  the  State  that  the  territorial  and  political  subdivisions  of  the  State  shall  enjoy 
genuine  and  meaningful  local  autonomy  to  enable  them  to  attain  their  fullest  development  as  self-reliant  communities  and 
make  them  more  effective  partners  in  the  attainment  of  national  goals.  Toward  this  end,  the  State  shall  provide  for  a  more 
responsive  and  accountable  local  government  structure  instituted  through  a  system  of  decentralization  whereby  local 
government units shall be given more powers, authority, responsibilities, and resources." The Department of the Interior and 
Local  Government  is  tasked  with  supporting  the  capacity  of  LGUs  to  create  programs  to  support  achieving  the  MDGs. The 
country  partnership  strategy  supported  by  the  country  operations  business  plan  (COBP)  2009–2010  supports  this  agenda.a 
Specifically, the COBP calls for continued support to policy dialogue  and development  partner  coordination, such as  ADB’s 
participation at the Working Group on Local Government and Decentralization, various technical assistance projects, and the 
Local Government Financing and Budget Reform (LGFBR). LGFBR subprogram 2 builds on the policy reforms implemented 
in subprogram 1.

1.  Key Issues  
The deceleration of the Philippine economy during the global financial crisis threatens to reverse recent gains and increase 
the number of poor. Economic growth in 2009 is estimated in the range of 1–2%, which translates into a decline in per capita 
incomes of –1.5% to zero. An ADB working paper indicated that the slowdown may significantly increase the number of poor 
in Asia. Developing Asia may face an increase of 40 million–60 million poor brought about by a 2–3 percentage point drop in 
GDP. In Southeast Asia, growth elasticity of poverty is estimated at –1.6, based on $1.25/day calculation. This high elasticity 
will compound the already worsening poverty incidence in the Philippines. ADB poverty assessment studies pointed out the 
increase in the number of poor families from 4.02 million in 2003 to 4.68 million in 2006, when the average growth rate was 
high at 5.3%.b The recent slowdown will further worsen the incidence of poverty.  
 
The Government of the Philippines (the Government) has responded through a fiscal stimulus package, which has increased 
the national Government deficit from less than 1% of GDP to a current estimate of 2.5%. These measures will be in the form 
of  increased  social  protection  programs,  a  scaled-up  conditional  cash-transfer  program,  a  larger  infrastructure  and  public 
employment  program,  and  tax  breaks  in  key  sectors.  Moreover,  local  governments  are  expected,  with  the  increase  in  their 
IRA in 2009, to contribute to achieving the priority national agenda. LGFBR subprogram 2 enhances performance and poverty 
monitoring  systems,  such  as  the  community-based  monitoring  system,  which  systematically  collects  poverty  profile  data  in 
provinces. These data will be the basis of direct local interventions in coordination with national poverty alleviation programs.
